name: Banowan-e-Afghan (2023-current)
description: Banowan-e-Afghan is a dine-in restaurant for women, run by women, a rarity in Taliban-controlled Afghanistan.

name: Afghanistan Community Kitchen (2023-current)
tags: food sovereignty, food shortage, food insecurity, kitchen
description: CARE-led Community kitchens in Afghanistan work to feed families in need. The cooks are community-based, and they prepare meals for their neighbors six days a week. These meals feed school children, drivers, shopkeepers, and families. (Source: CARE, 2024)

name: Milk Farmers Protest (2024)
tags: trade and global flows, farmers, agriculture
description: Over 1 million euros in 3 months go outside Albania for milk, while Albanian livestock farmers are treated unfairly and are not paid properly, Euronews Albania reports. (Source: Telegrafi, 2024)

country: Algeria, Croatia, Italy, Lebanon, Morocco, Tunisia
name: MountainHER (2022 - Current)
location: Algeria, Croatia, Italy, Lebanon, Morocco, Tunisia
description: MountainHER wants to put rural women front and center as the true drivers for social and economic progress in remote mountain communities of Algeria, Croatia, Italy, Lebanon, Morocco and Tunisia.

category: Community or Organization, Mutual Aid, Protest
name: Polo Obrero Picket Movement (1964 - current)
description: The Workers' Party of Marxist Unification (Partido Obrero de Unificación Marxista, POUM) was a Spanish communist party, independent from Moscow, which, although numerically small, played an important role in the Spanish civil war and revolution of 1936-9. It is often incorrectly described as Trotskyist. Source: libcom.org

country: Argentina, Columbia, Paraguay, Bolivia, Cuba, Peru, Brazil, Ecuador, Uruguay, Chile, Mexico, Venezuela
name: La Poderosa (2004 - Current)
description: An independent, grassroots social organization that represents various territories in impoverished neighborhoods in Latin America. They use the participatory methodology (inspired by Paulo Freire) as a tool for transformation and integration. In each neighborhood they organize activities that respond to the needs of that community. This includes supporting 150 soup kitchens, running 75 cooperatives, community health rooms, women and queer houses and a community sports center. Source: La Poderosa

region: Latin America and the Caribbean, Europe and Nothern America
name: Let Cuba Live: Bread For Our Neighbours (2024)
tags: trade and global flows, food shortage, bread, humanitarian aid
description: The People's Forum USA launched an emergency campaign to send 800 tons of wheat flour to Cuba as legal humanitarian aid, as the 66-year-long U.S. economic embargo on Cuba continues.

name: Food against Facism (2017 - 2018)
description: Food Against Fascism was a non-profit, community project that prepares and distributes free, hot, healthy meals every Saturday 12pm at De l’Eglise Metro, Galt and Wellingtion Verdun Montreal. Source: Food against Facism

name: Protest Mooncakes (2019)
location: Wah Yee Tang Cake Shop, Hong Kong
description: During Hong Kong's 2019 Anti-Extradition Protests, Wah Yee Tang Cake Shop, a family business that turns 35 this year, recently put mooncakes with protest messages on its menu, along with several other fiery options. Patrons can pick up handmade treats stamped with messages such as “No withdrawal, no dismissal” (不撤不散), “Hongkonger” (香港人), and “Freedom hi” (自由西). Aside from being beautiful (and no doubt, tasty), they are meant to inspire protestors fighting a controversial extradition bill. Source: Claire Voon for Atlas Obscura

name: Tear Gas Ice Cream (2020)
description: Sogno Gelato shop displays fierce anti-government protest art and memorabilia for sale. They also sell Tear Gas Ice Cream, created months after mass protests began in Hong Kong, initially in opposition to a change in extradition law. Asked why he launched the tear gas flavour, Chung, 32, said: “Which Hongkonger hasn’t tasted tear gas? This useless government fired so many tear gas canisters, even at nursing homes. As a Hongkonger we’ve had tear gas in Mong Kok, Tsim Sha Tsui, Tsuen Wan … everywhere. The government fired more than 16,000 rounds of tear gas at us.” (Source: Bernice Chan, South China Morning Post, 22 May 2020)

name: Salt March (1930)
description: The Salt March, which took place from March to April 1930 in India, was an act of civil disobedience led by Mohandas Gandhi to protest British rule in India. During the march, thousands of Indians followed Gandhi from his religious retreat near Ahmedabad to the Arabian Sea coast, a distance of some 240 miles. (Source: History.com)

name: Farmers Protest (2020-2021)
description: The Farmers’ Protest of 2020-2021 in India was a historic movement that drew widespread attention and support, primarily from farmer communities across the country. The protest, cantered around the capital city of Delhi, unfolded against the backdrop of contentious agricultural reforms introduced by the Indian government. Source: Ritimo

name: Bakudapan Food Study Group (2020-current)
description: BAKUDAPAN is an Indonesian study group that discuss ideas about food. The word BAKUDAPAN itself is inspired by “bakudapa”, which comes from Manadonese (North Sulawesi) language meaning to “meet”, and also “kudapan” which is a kind of snack that is usually served when there are activities such as a meeting, visiting, and even when hanging out. Therefore, “bakudapan” can be translated as eating snacks while meeting. Through this name, they would like to meet with people who have an interest in food. Source: Bakudapan Study Group

name: World's Largest Hummus (2010)
description: In October 2009, Lebanon reached a world record for a two-ton hummus plate. A few months later, Israel (occupied Palestine) broke Lebanon’s record with a four-ton dish, insisting to claim the dish theirs. Both countries have been trying to claim it as their own ‘national dish’, this was known as “The Hummus Wars.” To settle the argument, Lebanon broke the record again in May 2010, aiming to prove the dish is Lebanese. (Source: Souad Lazkani for 961, May 13 2020)

name: Orang Laut
description: Orang Laut (Malay for “sea people” or “people of the sea”) were nomadic sea gypsies organised into suku (divisions). They occupied the maritime zone surrounding the Strait of Melaka. During the period when the British thought Singapore was uninhabited, the Orang Laut had been using the island as one of the places to live in. As skilled mariners adept at controlling the seas, the Orang Laut played an important role in Malay political history. Source: National Library Board: Orang Laut

name: Mont Lone Yay Paw
description: Mont Lone Yay Paw is a traditional snack from Myanmar that was used in an anti-coup protest in April 2021. They are made from glutinous rice balls with palm sugar.

country: Myanmar, Thailand, Taiwan, Indonesia, Philippines, Malaysia, Japan, Hong Kong
name: Milk Tea Alliance (2020-current)
location: Myanmar, Thailand, Taiwan, Indonesia, Philippines, Malaysia, Japan, Hong Kong
description: #MilkTeaAlliance is a pan-Asia online civil solidarity movement that began in April 2020, but observers identified two distinct elements driving this movement: anti-China sentiment and a pro-democracy spirit. Source: Austin Horng-En Wang and Adrian Rauchfleisch, in their publication, 'Understanding the #MilkTeaAlliance Movement'

country: Myanmar, Thailand, Taiwan, Indonesia, Philippines, Malaysia, Japan, Hong Kong
name: Braiding Rice Seeds into Hair (1670 - 1860)
description: During the African slave trade, enslaved peoples found ways to retain their agency, and keep themselves and their cultures alive in ways that were not widely acknowledged by Western historians until the late 2000s. As Dutch slave owners forcibly transported people from West Africa to colonies in modern-day Brazil and throughout the Americas, some African women, namely rice farmers, braided rice seeds into their hair as a means for survival of themselves and the culture of their homeland. (Source: Shari Rose for Blurred Bylines, 2021)

name: Free Breakfast Program (1969 - 1980)
description: The Panthers started the Free Breakfast Program because hunger and poverty made it difficult for many poor black children to learn in school.

name: Soul Fire Farm (2010 - Current)
description: Soul Fire Farm is an Afro-Indigenous centered community farm and training center dedicated to uprooting racism and seeding sovereignty in the food system. Source: Soul Fire Farm

name: Black Farmer Fund (2020 - Current)
tags: food Sovereignty, farmers, black sovereignty, agriculture
description: Black Farmer Fund is driven by their unwavering commitment to empowering black farmers and fostering community health and wealth. They believe that a thriving AND SUSTAINABLE food system is not just essential for the WELLNESS OF OUR PEOPLE but also for THE PLANET. Source: Black Farmer Fund

name: People's Kitchen Collective (Current)
description: People's Kitchen Collective (PKC) works at the intersection of art and activism as a food-centered political education project. Based in Oakland, California, their creative practices reflect the diverse histories and backgrounds of our crew. Written in their families' recipes are the maps of our migrations and the stories of our resilience. It is from this foundation that they create immersive experiences that honor the shared struggles of our people. They believe in radical hospitality as a strategy to address the urgent social issues of our time. Source: People's Kitchen Collective

name: Food Not Bombs (1980 - current)
tags: free food, food shortage, food insecurity, vegetarian/vegan
description: Food Not Bombs is an all-volunteer movement that recovers food that would otherwise be discarded, and shares free vegan and vegetarian meals with the hungry in over 1,000 cities in 65 countries in protest to war, poverty, and destruction of the environment. Source: Food Not Bombs

name: Black Church Food Security Network (2015 - current)
tags: food Sovereignty, agriculture, religion, gardens, black sovereignty
description: Black Church Food Security Network helps black churches use their assets to establish gardens on their lands, host miniature farmer's markets and buy wholesale from black farmers. Source: Black Church Food Security Network

name: FIG NYC (2021 - current)
description: A grassroots collective working to transform the food system. FIG members are food workers committed to total transformation of the food system, from their home in New York / Lenapehoking and beyond. They envision a food future for all people where equity, sustainability, and community control are baked into the recipe — from New York City to the Hudson Valley, from Borikén to Palestine.

name: Street Vendor Project (2001 - current)
description: The Street Vendor Project is a membership-based project with more than 2,000 vendor members who are working together to create a vendors’ movement for permanent change. They advocate for the rights of street vendors in NYC. Source: Street Vendor Project

name: Shoebox Lunches (1890s - 1960s)
description: During Jim Crow, black travelers frequently carried shoebox meals as a means of staying safe when a Green Book site was not readily available. Although the Green Book provided safe places to eat, restaurants and safe places to stop could be few and far between. To keep their families safe, black women prepared shoe box meals. These meals frequently packaged in shoe boxes held foods that were less likely to spoil or require utensils. Meals generally included fried chicken, boiled or deviled eggs, fruit and vegetables, and pound cake. Source: Historic Magnolia Farm

name: Conflict Kitchen (2010-2017)
description: Conflict Kitchen (2010-2017) was a restaurant that served cuisine from countries with which the United States was in conflict.

name: Northeast Farmers of Color Land Trust (2018 - current)
description: The Northeast Farmers of Color Land Trust is a BIPOC-led organization dedicated to positively impacting the health and wellness outcomes of BIPOC communities and the lands and non-human beings in the Northeast region of what is now known as the United States

name: La Morada Mutual Aid (2008-current)
description: La Morada aims to reclaim Sanctuary and (Food) Sovereignty through Mutual Aid as the Practice of Urban Indigeneity and a Poetics of Liberation.  Establish in 2009 in the South Bronx (Source: Open Collective)

name: Everybody's Kitchen Bus (1992 - 2012)
tags: free food, disaster relief, food insecurity, kitchen
description: A free kitchen on wheels. Birthed in 1992, Everybody’s kitchen bus has been gathering, cooking and distributing food and resources, networking, connecting and encouraging community. They believe everyone has the human right to eat, whether you have a dime in your pocket or not. There is no hierarchy, no administration cost to everything they do. Source: William Bates for Everybody's Kitchen Bus in IndieGo, Jul 27, 2012

name: Palestine Heirloom Seed Library (2014-current)
description: The Palestine Heirloom Seed Library (PHSL) is an attempt to recover ancient seeds and their stories and put them back into people’s hands. The PHSL is an interactive art and agriculture project that aims to provide a conversation for people to exchange seeds and knowledge, and to tell the stories of food and agriculture that may have been buried away and waiting to sprout like a seed. It is also a place where visitors may feel inspired by the seed as a subversive rebel, of and for the people, traveling across borders and checkpoints to defy the violence of the landscape while reclaiming life and presence. (Source: Vivien Sansour, Palestina Heirloom Seed Library)

name: The Gaza Kitchen (2012)
description: This timely update of a much-loved, award-winning cookbook shares with readers the little-known but distinctive cuisine of the Gaza region of Palestine, presenting 130 recipes collected by the authors in Gaza. This edition includes new stories, recipes, and photos gathered during a late-2019 visit to Gaza by co-author Laila El-Haddad. (Source: Just World Books)

name: The Fishball Revolution (2016)
description: The protests began after Hong Kong police tried to issue tickets to unlicensed street food sellers in Mong Kok, a working class neighborhood. The violence appears to be borne out of a deep-seated mistrust about the direction Hong Kong is headed, under the leadership of a government that too often looks like it listens to Beijing more than its own people. Source: Richard Macauley and Heather Timmons for Quartz

name: Alliance for Food Sovereignty in Africa (AFSA) (2008-current)
description: The Alliance for Food Sovereignty in Africa (AFSA) is a broad alliance of different civil society actors that are part of the struggle for food sovereignty and agroecology in Africa. These include: African farmers’ organizations, African NGO networks, specialist African NGOs, consumer movements in Africa, international organizations which support the stance of AFSA, and individuals. Its members represent smallholder farmers, pastoralists, hunter/gatherers, indigenous peoples; faith based institutions, and environmentalists from across Africa.  It is a network of networks and currently with 30 active members. (Alliance for Food Sovereignty in Africa, 2019)

name: Mohamed Bouazizi, Food Vendor that catalysed the Arab Spring (2011)
description: Mohamed Bouazizi (born March 29, 1984, Sidi Bouzid, Tunisia—died January 4, 2011, Ben Arous, Tunisia) was a Tunisian street vendor whose self-immolation after being harassed by municipal officials catalyzed the Revolution for Dignity in Tunisia and helped inspire a wider pro-democracy protest movement in the Middle East and North Africa known as the Arab Spring. (Britannica,  Jan 1, 2025)

name: Farm School NYC (2007 - current)
description: Farm School NYC's mission is to train NYC residents in urban agriculture, build self-reliant communities, and inspire positive local action around food sovereignty and social, economic, and racial justice. Source: Farm School NYC

name: Corbin Hill Food Project (2009 - current)
description: Corbin Hill's mission is to disrupt and innovate within the extractive and oppressive food system and deal in the realities that face our communities as it relates to food access, food justice and food sovereignty. Source: Corbin Hill Food Project

name: Black Farmers United (current)
tags: food Sovereignty, black sovereignty, farmers, agriculture
description: Black Farmers United aims to protect the legacy and ensure the future of Black farmers. They hold the power to radically change how black communities control access to safe, healthy food, and build a collective wealth and health in New York State. Source: Black Farmers United

name: Food Served to Iraqi Protesters in Tahrir Square (2019)
description: In Baghdad’s Tahrir Square, there are the anti-government protesters demonstrating for a better future for Iraq, and there are the volunteers who feed them. From stuffed lamb and fish, to the giant pots of soups and rice, to the plates of lentils and other beans, there is no shortage of food to go around. Volunteers from the capital and southern provinces cook traditional dishes that reflect the country’s rich cuisine and bring protesters together. Source: AP News

name: Tales of Bread and Unfinished Revolution in Egypt (2011)
tags: arab spring, revolution, food shortage, bread
description: Baladi bread—a dense, round flatbread covered in bran—is the most common type of bread consumed in Egypt. Baladi bread also emerged as a central motif during the uprisings in Egypt a decade ago during the Arab Spring as shorthand for protesters’ demand for food. This bread is indicative of its storied history and political significance in the nation. Source: Marianne Dhenin for Life & Thyme, 6 April 2021

name: Staple Security: Bread and Wheat in Egypt (2022)
tags: bread, food shortage, food insecurity, trade and global flows, revolution
description: Egyptians often say that bread is life; most eat this staple multiple times a day, many relying on the cheap bread subsidized by the government. In Staple Security, Jessica Barnes explores the process of sourcing domestic and foreign wheat for the production of bread and its consumption across urban and rural settings. She traces the anxiety that pervades Egyptian society surrounding the possibility that the nation could run out of wheat or that people might not have enough good bread to eat, and the daily efforts to ensure that this does not happen. With rich ethnographic detail, she takes us into the worlds of cultivating wheat, trading grain, and baking, buying, and eating bread. Linking global flows of grain and a national bread subsidy program with everyday household practices, Barnes theorizes the nexus between food and security, drawing attention to staples and the lengths to which people go to secure their consistent availability and quality. (Source: Jessica Barnes for Staple Security, Duke University Press, September 2022)

category: Community or Organization, Mutual Aid, Protest
name: Georgia Gilmore and The Club From Nowhere (1955)
tags: black sovereignty, kitchen, civil rights movement
description: Georgia Teresa Gilmore was an African-American woman from Montgomery, Alabama, who participated in the Montgomery bus boycott through her fund-raising organization, the Club from Nowhere, which sold food at Montgomery Improvement Association (MIA) mass meetings. Source: Maria Godoy for NPR, 15 Jan 2018

name: 96-hour hunger strike by Kisan Baburao Hazare (2011)
description: Kisan Baburao 'Anna' Hazare is an Indian social activist who led movements to promote rural development, increase government transparency, and investigate and punish corruption in public life. Hazare conducted a 12-day hunger strike from 5 - 17 April - to exert pressure on the Indian government to enact a stringent anti-corruption law. The fast led to nationwide protests in support. The fast ended a day after the government accepted Hazare's demands. Source: BBC News, 9 April 2011

name: Boston Tea Party (1773)
description: Boston Tea Party, (December 16, 1773), incident in which 342 chests of tea belonging to the British East India Company were thrown from ships into Boston Harbor by American patriots disguised as Mohawk Indians. The Americans were protesting both a tax on tea (taxation without representation) and the perceived monopoly of the East India Company. Source: Britannica, 2024

name: Online Memory Restaurant with Holodomor dishes (current)
description: Students of the Ukrainian Leadership Academy created the world’s first online memory restaurant with dishes cooked using the products that Ukrainians could find during the Holodomor of 1932-33. The project is meant to honor the memory of the innocent people who died during the famine. Source: Ukrainian Recipes, 2024

name: Uncounted Since 1932 (2017)
description: 'UNCOUNTED Since 1932' was a pop-up restaurant by a group of Ukrainian students and activists that served dishes to the residents of Brussels, Belgium, aimed at raising awareness in Europe about Stalin-era famine in Ukraine in 1932-33, known as the Holodomor. The dishes served included soup made from pine cones, bread made from grass and pancakes made out of tree bark.The “uncounted” refers to people who died from the famine without being recorded, as the Soviet authorities kept the artificially-produced famine top-secret, both inside the country and abroad. Source: Kyiv Post, 2018

name: Watermelon as a symbol of Kherson’s liberation (2022)
description: During peacetime, watermelons played an important role in promoting tourism in the region. During the war, the watermelon became a symbol of the region’s liberation from Russian occupation. Because of the war, most Ukrainians were unable to taste Kherson watermelons this summer. Kherson watermelons were only marketed in the occupied territory in Ukraine. Watermelons taken from the Kherson region were also exported to Russia. Source: We are Ukraine, 2022

name: Olive oil from Palestine (current)
description: 'Campaign Olive Oil' is an association based in Zurich in accordance with the Swiss Civil Code. It imports olive oil from Palestine, for which the farmers are paid a fair price, and sells it in campaigns in Switzerland. The institution does not pursue commercial purposes and does not seek to make a profit. Any surplus from sales goes into project work, which in turn must not be profit-oriented. Source: Fundraiso

name: The Hungry Steppe: Famine, Violence, and the Making of Soviet Kazakstan (2015)
description: This book highlights the Kazakh famine of 1930-33 as one of the most heinous crimes of the Stanlinist regime- More than 1.5 million people perished, and the crisis transformed a territory the size of continental Europe. Yet, the story of this famine remained largely hidden from view, both in Kazakhstan and in the West. The book brings this largely unknown story to light and explores how this famine alters our understanding of Soviet modernization and nation-making. Source: Sarah Cameron for Harry Frank Guggenheim Foundation, 2015

name: The Refugee Food project (2016-current)
description: Refugee Food is a global project led by an association, whose objective is to raise awareness about the situation of refugees, accelerate the professional integration of refugees in the restaurant industry, and work towards tasty, fair, and sustainable food for all. Born in the form of a culinary festival in 2016, the project has since diversified considerably to become a global project responding to the various challenges of reception and integration in France. Source: The Refugee Food Project

name: Prison Agriculture Lab (2019-current)
tags: prison, black sovereignty, agriculture, study group
description: The Prison Agriculture Lab is a collaborative space for inquiry and action that focuses on agriculture in the criminal punishment system. Source: Prison Agriculture Lab
